A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Factor Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Factor Group inherently relies on the concept of a Group. The Factor Group is defined as a set of cosets of a normal subgroup $N$ in a group $G$, with a specific group operation. This definition presupposes the existence of a group $G$ and a subgroup $N$ which itself must also be a group. Without the concept of a Group, the notion of a subgroup, and hence a normal subgroup, would not exist. Furthermore, the operations and properties (like associativity, identity, and inverses) used in defining the Factor Group are derived from the properties of a Group. Therefore, understanding and defining a Factor Group is contingent upon first understanding what a Group is.
